Perform Linear Regression with Comprehensive Diagnostics

Source: R/regression.R
analyze_regression.Rd

Conducts linear regression analysis with explicit assumption testing, diagnostic plots, and publication-ready output. Supports both simple (one predictor) and multiple (many predictors) regression.

Usage

analyze_regression(
  data,
  formula,
  check_assumptions = TRUE,
  create_plots = TRUE,
  alpha = 0.05,
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

data

Data frame containing variables

formula

Formula specifying the model, e.g., y ~ x or y ~ x1 + x2 + x3

check_assumptions

Logical. Test regression assumptions? Default is TRUE

create_plots

Logical. Create diagnostic plots? Default is TRUE

alpha

Significance level (default 0.05)

verbose

Logical. Show detailed explanations? Default is TRUE

Value

A list containing:

  • model_type: "Simple" or "Multiple" regression

  • coefficients: Table of regression coefficients with tests

  • r_squared: R^2 value

  • adj_r_squared: Adjusted R^2 value

  • f_statistic: Overall model F-statistic

  • f_df1: F-statistic numerator df

  • f_df2: F-statistic denominator df

  • p_value: Overall model p-value

  • significant: Is overall model significant?

  • rmse: Root mean squared error

  • n_observations: Sample size

  • assumptions: Assumption check results (if requested)

  • diagnostic_plots: ggplot2 diagnostic plots (if requested)

  • publication_text: Publication-ready text

  • interpretation: Plain English interpretation

  • lm_model: Full lm() model object

Details

## Regression Assumptions:

  • Linearity: Relationship between X and Y is linear

  • Independence: Residuals are independent

  • Homoscedasticity: Constant variance of residuals

  • Normality: Residuals are normally distributed

  • No multicollinearity: Predictors aren't highly correlated (multiple regression)

## R^2 Interpretation:

  • 0.01 - 0.09: Small effect

  • 0.09 - 0.25: Medium effect

  • 0.25+: Large effect

Examples

# Example 1: Simple regression
data <- data.frame(
  ad_spending = c(100, 200, 150, 300, 250, 400, 350, 500),
  sales = c(20, 35, 28, 48, 42, 65, 58, 80)
)
result <- analyze_regression(data, sales ~ ad_spending)
#> 
#> Fitting linear regression model...
#> Model fitted successfully (n = 8, predictors = 1)
#> Checking regression assumptions...
#> Warning: Unrecognized data_structure
#> ! You provided: 'cross-sectional regression'
#> ℹ Common options: cross-sectional survey, repeated measures, time series
#> → Proceeding with custom structure, but results may be less specific
#> Warning: Very small sample size
#> ! n = 8 (after removing 0 missing)
#> ℹ Normality tests are unreliable with n < 10
#> ℹ The Shapiro-Wilk test needs larger samples for reliable results
#> ! Recommendations:
#>   • Collect more data if possible
#>   • Use visual inspection (Q-Q plot, histogram)
#>   • Consider non-parametric tests as safer option
#> → Results should be interpreted with extreme caution
#> Assumption checks complete.
#> Creating diagnostic plots...
#> Regression analysis complete!

# Example 2: Multiple regression
data <- data.frame(
  satisfaction = c(7, 8, 6, 9, 5, 8, 7, 6, 9, 8),
  price = c(10, 8, 12, 7, 15, 9, 11, 13, 8, 10),
  quality = c(8, 9, 7, 9, 6, 8, 7, 6, 9, 8),
  service = c(7, 8, 6, 9, 5, 8, 7, 7, 9, 8)
)
result <- analyze_regression(data, satisfaction ~ price + quality + service)
#> 
#> Fitting linear regression model...
#> Model fitted successfully (n = 10, predictors = 3)
#> Checking regression assumptions...
#> Warning: Unrecognized data_structure
#> ! You provided: 'cross-sectional regression'
#> ℹ Common options: cross-sectional survey, repeated measures, time series
#> → Proceeding with custom structure, but results may be less specific
#> Assumption checks complete.
#> Creating diagnostic plots...
#> Regression analysis complete!

# View publication text
print(result, show_publication = TRUE)
#>

#>   the outcome. Significant predictor(s): service. See coefficients table
#>   for details.

#> 
#> ASSUMPTIONS:
#>   The data were collected using a cross-sectional regression design, ensuring
#>   independence of observations. Data normality was assessed using the
#>   Shapiro-Wilk test. The regression residuals variable met the normality
#>   assumption (W = 0.9458, p = .619). Homoscedasticity was assessed using the
#>   Breusch-Pagan test. The assumption was met (chi^2 = 0.33, p = 0.5638),
#>   indicating constant error variance. Multicollinearity was assessed using
#>   Variance Inflation Factors (VIF). Some VIF values exceeded 5, indicating
#>   moderate to high multicollinearity. Interpretation of individual coefficients
#>   should be made with caution.
#> 
#> 
#> METHODS:
#>   Linear regression analysis was conducted to examine the relationship between
#>   the predictor variable(s) and the outcome variable. Regression assumes
#>   linearity, independence of residuals, homoscedasticity of residuals, and
#>   normality of residuals.
#> 
#> 
#> RESULTS:
#>   The overall regression model was statistically significant (F = 98.96, p <
#>   .001, R^2 = 0.98).
#> 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   These results provide evidence of a statistically significant effect.
#> 
#> 
#> ADDITIONAL NOTES:
#>   The regression model included 3 predictor(s) and was based on 10
#>   observations. RMSE = 0.179.
#> 
#> 
#> 
#> USAGE NOTE:
#>   Copy the sections above into your manuscript. Modify as needed for your
#>   specific journal's requirements and integrate with your narrative.
#> 
#> 
#> Tip: Use print(result, show_assumptions = TRUE) to see assumption checks
#>
